intro.title: Welcome to the Salah Journey
intro.description: Salah is the second pillar of Islam, the connection between a servant and Allah. Every Muslim who has reached puberty must pray 5 times daily.

6. Wash face 3 times

8. Wipe head once
9. Wipe ears once

hajj.description: Learn every step of performing Hajj in the holy city of Makkah

intro.title: Welcome to the Hajj Journey
intro.description: Hajj is the fifth pillar of Islam, obligatory for every Muslim who is capable, at least once in their lifetime. A sacred journey to Baytullah.
intro.hadith: Whoever performs Hajj for Allah and does not speak obscenely or commit sins, he will return like the day his mother gave birth to him

steps.title: Preparation
steps.description: Prepare physically and spiritually before departure
details: Pay off debts and seek forgiveness from others
Write a will (wasiyyah)
Prepare halal funds for the journey
Study and understand the Hajj rituals
Prepare physically for the journey
Make sincere intention for Allah
steps.tips: An accepted Hajj (Hajj Mabrur) has no reward other than Paradise

steps.title: Wearing Ihram
steps.description: Wear Ihram garments and make intention at the Miqat
details: Take a bath and cleanse yourself
Men: Wear two white unsewn cloths
Women: Wear normal modest clothing

waterTypes.title: Types of Water
waterTypes.description: Learn about the types of water used for purification in Islam

steps.title: Mutlaq Water (Pure Water)
steps.description: Pure water that can be used for wudu and ghusl
details: Rain water - Water that Allah sends down from the sky
Well water - Water that springs from the ground
River water - Naturally flowing water
Sea water - Salt water that is considered clean
Melted snow or ice
Tap water - Filtered water
steps.tips: Mutlaq water is the best for performing wudu and ghusl

steps.title: Musta'mal Water (Used Water)
steps.description: Water that has been used for wudu or ghusl
details: Water that has flowed over the body during wudu
Water used for ghusl al-janabah
According to some schools, it cannot be used to remove hadath again
Other opinions allow it if still clean
steps.tips: It is recommended to always use fresh water when possible

steps.title: Mutanajjis Water (Impure Water)
steps.description: Water contaminated with impurity that changes its properties
details: Water whose color has changed due to impurity
Water whose smell has changed due to impurity
Water whose taste has changed due to impurity
Cannot be used for purification
Must be purified before use
steps.tips: Water with impurity that doesn't change its properties is still considered pure if the quantity is large (2 qullah)

steps.title: Mukhallat Water (Mixed Water)
steps.description: Water mixed with other substances that changed its properties
details: Tea, coffee, fruit juice
Water mixed with thick soap
Water heavily mixed with perfume
Cannot be used for wudu or ghusl
Still considered clean (tahir) and drinkable
steps.tips: The difference between mutanajjis and mukhallat is that mukhallat is still clean but cannot remove hadath

completed.title: Congratulations!

steps.title: Why don't Muslims eat pork?
steps.description: The prohibition of pork is a clear command from Allah in the Quran, which Muslims follow out of faith and obedience.
details: Allah explicitly forbids it in the Quran (Surah Al-Baqarah 2:173)
This prohibition also exists in the Torah and Bible (Leviticus 11:7-8)

Pork contains parasites and diseases like tapeworm and trichinosis

steps.tips: Following Allah's commands is an act of faith, even when we don't fully understand the reasons

The key condition is treating all wives with absolute justice and equality

steps.title: Why don't Muslims drink alcohol?
steps.description: Alcohol and intoxicants are forbidden in Islam because they destroy the intellect and cause many social problems.
details: The Quran explicitly forbids it, calling it 'rijs' (filth)
It destroys the intellect, which Allah values highly
It causes crime, accidents, and family problems
It damages health - liver, brain, and other organs
It causes neglect of duties to Allah, like abandoning prayer
The Prophet ï·º cursed producers, sellers, drinkers, and all involved
The prohibition came gradually to help people adjust
steps.tips: There are many halal beverage alternatives that are healthy

steps.title: Why do Muslims face the Qiblah?
steps.description: The Qiblah (direction of the Kaaba) is the direction all Muslims worldwide face when praying, symbolizing unity.
details: The Kaaba is the first house built for worshipping Allah
It was built by Prophet Ibrahim and Prophet Ismail
It symbolizes the unity of Muslims worldwide
Muslims don't worship the Kaaba - they worship Allah while facing it
Originally the Qiblah was Al-Aqsa Mosque before being changed to the Kaaba
Facing the same direction represents unity
The Kaaba is in Makkah, the holiest city

steps.title: Why do Muslims only eat halal food?
steps.description: Halal food is food permitted by Islamic law, with specific rules about the type and slaughter method.
details: Halal means 'permissible' - Haram means 'forbidden'
Animals must be slaughtered properly while mentioning Allah's name
Blood vessels and windpipe must be cut to drain all blood
Blood is considered forbidden in Islam
Animals that die naturally, are strangled, or beaten to death are forbidden
Most seafood is halal without requiring slaughter
Vegetables, fruits, and grains are naturally halal
steps.tips: Look for halal certification on products or ask vendors before buying

steps.title: Do Muslims believe in Jesus?
steps.description: Muslims believe in Prophet Isa (Jesus) as a great prophet and messenger, but not as God or the son of God.
details: Prophet Isa is one of the greatest prophets (Ulul Azm)
Muslims believe he was born to Maryam (Mary) without a father (a miracle)
He performed many miracles by Allah's permission
Muslims don't believe he was the son of God or God himself
Muslims don't believe he was crucified
Muslims believe he was raised to heaven and will return before the End Times
Muslims say 'Peace be upon him' when mentioning his name
steps.tips: Muslims hold Prophet Isa and Lady Maryam in very high esteem

steps.title: Why does Islam forbid interest/usury?
steps.description: Interest (Riba) is forbidden in Islam because it is exploitative and creates economic injustice.
details: The Quran strictly and severely prohibits Riba
Those who consume interest are declared war upon by Allah and His Messenger
Interest makes the rich richer and the poor poorer
It is earning money without work or risk
Islam encourages trade and profit-loss sharing (Musharakah)
Islamic banks use profit-sharing systems instead
Both giving and taking interest is forbidden
steps.tips: Today there are many Islamic financial products that are interest-free

steps.title: Why do Muslims fast in Ramadan?
steps.description: Fasting in Ramadan is the fourth pillar of Islam, providing spiritual and physical benefits.
details: It is commanded by Allah (Surah Al-Baqarah 2:183)
Ramadan is the month when the Quran was revealed
It trains patience, self-control, and God-consciousness (Taqwa)
It creates empathy by experiencing the hunger of the poor
It detoxifies and rests the digestive system
It is an opportunity for seeking forgiveness and increasing worship
The gates of Paradise open, gates of Hell close, and devils are chained
steps.tips: Fasting is not just abstaining from food - it includes abstaining from all bad things

steps.title: Why do Muslims go for Hajj?
steps.description: Hajj is the fifth pillar of Islam - a pilgrimage to Makkah required once in a lifetime for those who are able.
details: It is commanded by Allah for those who have the ability
Performing it once in a lifetime is sufficient
It is the largest gathering of Muslims from around the world
Everyone wears the same white clothes, showing equality
One who performs Hajj correctly has all sins forgiven
It retraces the history of Prophet Ibrahim
It is training in patience and sacrifice
steps.tips: Hajj is obligatory only for those who are physically and financially capable

prophetBiography.title: Biography of Prophet Muhammad ï·º
prophetBiography.description: Learn about the life of Prophet Muhammad ï·º from birth to death, covering all significant events

steps.title: Year of the Elephant
steps.description: The year Prophet Muhammad ï·º was born, when Abraha tried to destroy the Kaaba
details: In 570 CE, the Abyssinian ruler Abraha came to destroy the Kaaba
He brought a large army with elephants
Allah sent flocks of birds carrying stones of baked clay
The army was completely destroyed
This is mentioned in Surah Al-Fil in the Quran
The Prophet ï·º was born in this blessed year
steps.tips: This event shows Allah's protection of His sacred house

steps.title: Birth of the Prophet ï·º
steps.description: Prophet Muhammad ï·º was born on Monday, 12th Rabi al-Awwal
details: Born in Makkah in the Year of the Elephant (570 CE)
His father Abdullah died before his birth
His mother was Aminah bint Wahb
He was born into the noble Hashim clan of Quraysh
His grandfather Abdul Muttalib named him 'Muhammad' (The Praised One)
Signs and miracles accompanied his birth
steps.tips: The Prophet ï·º said: 'I am the answered prayer of Ibrahim'

steps.title: Childhood with Halimah
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º was nursed by Halimah al-Sa'diyyah in the desert
details: It was Arab custom to send children to the desert for nursing
Halimah initially hesitated due to his orphan status
After taking him, her family was blessed with abundance
The opening of his chest occurred during this period
Angels came and purified his heart
He stayed with Halimah until age 4-5
steps.tips: This period helped him learn pure Arabic and develop a strong character

steps.title: Death of His Mother
steps.description: Aminah passed away when the Prophet ï·º was 6 years old
details: She died while returning from visiting relatives in Madinah
She passed away at Abwa, between Makkah and Madinah
The young Muhammad ï·º was now a complete orphan
His grandfather Abdul Muttalib then took care of him
Allah mentions orphans' care in the Quran due to this
This experience made him compassionate towards orphans
steps.tips: The Prophet ï·º encouraged caring for orphans throughout his life

steps.title: Under His Uncle's Care
steps.description: After Abdul Muttalib's death, Abu Talib raised the Prophet ï·º
details: Abdul Muttalib died when Muhammad ï·º was 8 years old
Abu Talib took him in despite having many children
He loved Muhammad ï·º more than his own children
He took him on trading journeys to Syria
Abu Talib protected him until his own death
Though he never became Muslim, Abu Talib defended Islam
steps.tips: Abu Talib's protection was crucial in the early days of Islam

steps.title: Meeting Monk Bahira
steps.description: The Christian monk Bahira recognized signs of prophethood in young Muhammad ï·º
details: This occurred during a trade journey to Syria
Bahira saw a cloud shading the caravan
He noticed the Seal of Prophethood between his shoulders
Bahira warned Abu Talib to protect him
He recognized signs from previous scriptures
Muhammad ï·º was about 12 years old
steps.tips: This shows that people of knowledge recognized his prophethood before revelation

steps.title: The Fijar War
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º witnessed warfare during his youth
details: This war occurred between Quraysh and Hawazin tribes
The Prophet ï·º was about 15-20 years old
He participated by collecting arrows for his uncles
He witnessed the horrors of tribal warfare
This experience influenced his later peacemaking
He later called it a 'war of transgression'
steps.tips: These experiences shaped his character as a peacemaker

steps.title: Alliance of the Virtuous (Hilf al-Fudul)
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º participated in an alliance to support the oppressed
details: This alliance was formed after the Fijar War
Members pledged to help the oppressed regardless of tribe
It was formed in the house of Abdullah ibn Jud'an
The Prophet ï·º said he would honor it even after Islam
This shows Islam's values existed before revelation
It established principles of justice and human rights
steps.tips: The Prophet ï·º said: 'If I were called to it in Islam, I would respond'

steps.title: Working as a Shepherd
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º worked as a shepherd in his youth
details: He herded sheep for the people of Makkah
All prophets were shepherds at some point
This taught him patience and responsibility
He said: 'Every prophet herded sheep'
It developed his contemplative nature
Shepherding requires constant vigilance and care
steps.tips: Shepherding developed qualities needed for leading a nation

steps.title: Trading for Khadijah
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º worked as a trader for the noble Khadijah
details: Khadijah was a successful businesswoman in Makkah
She heard of Muhammad's honesty and trustworthiness
She hired him to trade with her caravan to Syria
Her servant Maysarah accompanied him
The journey was extremely profitable
His honesty and character impressed Khadijah
steps.tips: His title 'Al-Amin' (The Trustworthy) preceded his prophethood

steps.title: Marriage to Khadijah
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º married Khadijah when he was 25 years old
details: Khadijah proposed marriage through her friend
She was about 40 years old, he was 25
She was previously married twice and was a widow
Abu Talib conducted the marriage ceremony
They had 6 children: 2 sons and 4 daughters
She was his only wife until her death
steps.tips: Khadijah was the first to believe in his prophethood

steps.title: Rebuilding the Kaaba
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º resolved a dispute during the Kaaba's reconstruction
details: The Kaaba was damaged by flooding
Tribes disputed who would place the Black Stone
They agreed the next person entering would decide
Muhammad ï·º was that person
He placed the stone on a cloth, each tribe held a corner
Then he placed the stone himself
steps.tips: This wisdom prevented bloodshed and earned him great respect

steps.title: Seclusion in Cave Hira
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º would spend time in contemplation in Cave Hira
details: He began this practice before revelation
The cave is on Jabal al-Nur (Mountain of Light)
He would bring provisions for several nights
Khadijah would send him food and water
He pondered about the Creator and creation
This prepared him for receiving revelation
steps.tips: Contemplation and reflection are important in Islam

steps.title: The First Revelation
steps.description: Angel Jibreel came with the first verses of the Quran
details: This occurred in the month of Ramadan, 610 CE
The Prophet ï·º was 40 years old
Jibreel commanded him to 'Read' (Iqra)
The first 5 verses of Surah Al-Alaq were revealed
He was terrified and rushed home to Khadijah
She comforted him and took him to her cousin Waraqah
steps.tips: The first word revealed was 'Read' - emphasizing knowledge

steps.title: Secret Preaching Period
steps.description: The first 3 years of Islam were preached secretly
details: The Prophet ï·º invited close family and friends first
The first Muslims: Khadijah, Abu Bakr, Ali, Zayd
Abu Bakr brought many prominent Makkans to Islam
They prayed secretly in homes and remote areas
This period built a solid foundation of believers
About 40 people accepted Islam during this time
steps.tips: Starting with a strong core group is crucial for any movement

steps.title: Public Preaching
steps.description: Allah commanded the Prophet ï·º to preach openly
details: The command came: 'Warn your closest relatives'
He climbed Mount Safa to address Quraysh
He asked if they would believe him about an army
They said yes, as he never lied
He then warned them of Allah's punishment
Abu Lahab cursed him, leading to Surah Lahab
steps.tips: Speaking truth publicly requires courage and conviction

steps.title: Persecution of Muslims
steps.description: The Quraysh severely persecuted the early Muslims
details: Bilal was tortured in the desert sun
The family of Yasir was killed, making them first martyrs
The Prophet ï·º himself was harassed and mocked
Muslims were boycotted economically and socially
Some were forced to emigrate to Abyssinia
The boycott lasted 3 years
steps.tips: Patience in hardship is a test of true faith

steps.title: Year of Sorrow
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º lost both Khadijah and Abu Talib
details: In 619 CE, both supporters died within months
Khadijah was his emotional and spiritual support
Abu Talib was his political protector
Persecution intensified after their deaths
He traveled to Taif seeking support but was rejected
This was one of the hardest periods of his life
steps.tips: Even in darkest times, trust in Allah's plan

steps.title: Isra and Mi'raj
steps.description: The miraculous night journey and ascension to heaven
details: Occurred about a year after the Year of Sorrow
He was taken from Makkah to Jerusalem in one night
Then ascended through the seven heavens
Met previous prophets including Ibrahim and Musa
The five daily prayers were prescribed
He saw Jannah and Jahannam
steps.tips: This journey was a gift from Allah after great hardship

steps.title: The Hijrah to Madinah
steps.description: The migration from Makkah to Madinah marks the Islamic calendar
details: Occurred in 622 CE after 13 years in Makkah
The Quraysh plotted to kill him
He escaped with Abu Bakr, hiding in Cave Thawr
He arrived in Madinah on 12th Rabi al-Awwal
The Ansar of Madinah welcomed them joyfully
This marks year 1 of the Islamic calendar
steps.tips: Sometimes leaving home is necessary for a greater purpose

steps.title: Establishing the State in Madinah
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º established the first Islamic state
details: Built the Prophet's Mosque as the center
Created brotherhood between Muhajirun and Ansar
Drafted the Constitution of Madinah
Established treaties with Jewish tribes
Set up the market and economy
Created a system of governance
steps.tips: Islam provides guidance for both spiritual and civic life

steps.title: The Farewell Pilgrimage
steps.description: The Prophet's ï·º final pilgrimage and sermon
details: Performed in 632 CE (10 AH)
Over 100,000 Muslims accompanied him
He delivered his famous Farewell Sermon at Arafat
Declared equality of all humans regardless of race
Emphasized women's rights and brotherhood
The verse 'Today I have perfected your religion' was revealed
steps.tips: His final sermon contains timeless principles for humanity

steps.title: Death of the Prophet ï·º
steps.description: The Prophet ï·º passed away on Monday, 12th Rabi al-Awwal 11 AH
details: He fell ill after the Farewell Pilgrimage
He passed away in the lap of Aisha
His last words were about prayer and treating servants well
Abu Bakr announced his death to the shocked community
He was buried in Aisha's room, now in the Prophet's Mosque
He was 63 years old
steps.tips: His message lives on through the Quran and Sunnah

completed.title: Journey Complete
completed.message: You have learned about the blessed life of Prophet Muhammad ï·º
completed.dua: O Allah, send blessings upon Muhammad and the family of Muhammad. Ameen

islamicBattles.title: Major Battles in Islamic History
islamicBattles.description: Learn about the significant battles during the Prophet's ï·º time, their causes, and lessons

steps.title: Battle of Badr
steps.description: The first major battle of Islam - a decisive victory against the Quraysh
details: Occurred on 17th Ramadan, 2 AH (624 CE)
313 Muslims faced 1,000 Quraysh fighters
Allah sent angels to support the Muslims
70 enemies killed, 70 captured
Key Quraysh leaders like Abu Jahl were killed
Known as 'The Day of Criterion' (Yawm al-Furqan)
steps.tips: Victory comes from Allah, not from numbers or strength

steps.title: Battle of Uhud
steps.description: A battle with lessons about following the Prophet's commands
details: Occurred in Shawwal, 3 AH (625 CE)
Quraysh came with 3,000 men seeking revenge for Badr
Muslims numbered about 700 after hypocrites withdrew
Initial victory turned to loss when archers left their post
The Prophet ï·º was injured and rumors spread of his death
70 Muslims were martyred including Hamzah
steps.tips: Disobedience to leadership can lead to disaster

steps.title: Battle of the Trench (Khandaq)
steps.description: The siege of Madinah and the strategy of the trench
details: Occurred in Shawwal, 5 AH (627 CE)
A coalition of 10,000 fighters besieged Madinah
Salman al-Farisi suggested digging a trench
The siege lasted about a month
Allah sent wind and angels to scatter the enemy
This was the last major Quraysh offensive
steps.tips: Strategic thinking and preparation are important in Islam

steps.title: Banu Qurayzah Campaign
steps.description: Dealing with treachery during the Battle of the Trench
details: Occurred immediately after the Battle of the Trench
Banu Qurayzah broke their treaty during the siege
They conspired with the enemy against the Muslims
The Prophet ï·º besieged them for 25 days
They surrendered and asked for arbitration
Sa'd ibn Mu'adh judged according to their own scripture
steps.tips: Betrayal of trust has serious consequences

steps.title: Treaty of Hudaybiyyah
steps.description: The peace treaty that Allah called a 'clear victory'
details: Occurred in Dhul Qi'dah, 6 AH (628 CE)
Muslims set out for Umrah but were stopped at Hudaybiyyah
A 10-year peace treaty was negotiated
Terms seemed unfavorable to Muslims initially
Allah revealed Surah Al-Fath calling it a victory
Islam spread rapidly during the peace period
steps.tips: Sometimes apparent setbacks are actually victories

steps.title: Battle of Khaybar
steps.description: The conquest of the Jewish fortress of Khaybar
details: Occurred in Muharram, 7 AH (628 CE)
Khaybar Jews had been plotting against Muslims
Ali ibn Abi Talib was given the banner
He defeated the champion Marhab in single combat
The fortresses were conquered one by one
Jews were allowed to stay and farm the land
steps.tips: True strength comes from faith, not physical power alone

steps.title: Battle of Mu'tah
steps.description: The first battle against the Byzantine Empire
details: Occurred in Jumada al-Awwal, 8 AH (629 CE)
3,000 Muslims faced 200,000 Byzantine and Arab forces
Three commanders were martyred: Zayd, Ja'far, Abdullah
Khalid ibn al-Walid took command and saved the army
The Prophet ï·º announced the deaths by revelation
This showed Muslim willingness to face superpowers
steps.tips: Leadership and strategic retreat can save an army

steps.title: Conquest of Makkah
steps.description: The peaceful conquest of Makkah
details: Occurred in Ramadan, 8 AH (630 CE)
Quraysh broke the Treaty of Hudaybiyyah
The Prophet ï·º marched with 10,000 Muslims
Makkah surrendered peacefully
The Prophet ï·º granted general amnesty
He destroyed the idols around the Kaaba
steps.tips: Forgiveness in victory shows true nobility of character

steps.title: Battle of Hunayn
steps.description: A lesson about relying on Allah, not numbers
details: Occurred in Shawwal, 8 AH (630 CE)
Hawazin and Thaqif tribes gathered 20,000 fighters
Muslims numbered 12,000 - their largest army
Initial pride in numbers led to initial defeat
The Prophet ï·º rallied them and victory came
Allah mentions this in Surah At-Tawbah
steps.tips: Numbers mean nothing without Allah's support

steps.title: Siege of Taif
steps.description: The unsuccessful siege after Hunayn
details: Occurred after the Battle of Hunayn in 8 AH
The Thaqif tribe retreated to their fortified city
Muslims besieged Taif for about 20 days
The siege was lifted without conquest
The Prophet ï·º prayed for Thaqif's guidance
Thaqif accepted Islam the following year
steps.tips: Sometimes patience achieves what force cannot

steps.title: Expedition of Tabuk
steps.description: The march to face the Byzantine army
details: Occurred in Rajab, 9 AH (630 CE)
Rumors of Byzantine army gathering at the border
The Prophet ï·º led 30,000 men in extreme heat
Known as the 'Expedition of Hardship'
No battle occurred as the enemy retreated
It established Muslim power in the north
steps.tips: Responding to threats shows strength even without fighting

steps.title: Lessons from the Battles
steps.description: Key lessons from the Prophet's military campaigns
details: The Prophet ï·º participated in 27 expeditions
Only 9 involved actual fighting
Total Muslim casualties in all battles: about 250
The Prophet ï·º always sought peace first
Strict rules of warfare were established
Protection of civilians, trees, and religious sites was mandated
steps.tips: Islamic warfare has strict ethical rules unlike any other

completed.title: Journey Complete
completed.message: You have learned about the major battles in Islamic history
completed.dua: O Allah, grant us understanding of our history and guide us. Ameen
